awd_titl_txt: Deciphering the roles of differential type IV pilin expression and N-glycosylation in biofilm formation
awd_abstract_narration:
PI Name:  Pohlschroder, Mechthild

PI Institution:  University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA

Proposal title:  Microbial biofilms: Deciphering the roles of differential type IV pilin expression and N-glycosylation

Microbes including bacteria, archaea, algae, and fungi can form communities that are embedded in protective polymeric matrices, called biofilms. These biofilms can be beneficial, for example when making vinegar.  But biofilms can also cause great harm as they can be tough and extremely difficult to eradicate, causing for example substantial corrosion and clogging of water and sewage pipes and of the pipelines used to transport oil and gas, as well as crop damage and food spoilage; thus they have significant negative impacts on the economy. This project will address the biological processes that regulate and facilitate the establishment and spread of biofilms and thus will result in a greatly improved understanding of biofilm formation.  In particular, we aim to understand the role cell surface structures, termed pilins, and sugar-modifications of proteins play in biofilm formation.  We will use cutting edge mass spectrometric (MS) technology to characterize at the molecular level biofilm formation in an archaea model organism, Haloferax volcanii.  Our research will not only advance the scientific knowledge in this exciting and timely field of research, but will also provide post-doctoral associates, graduate, undergraduate, and high school students with invaluable training opportunities to study microbiological systems with novel, state-of-the-art technologies. Furthermore, the Pohlschroder lab will take part in science education programs in hopes of stimulating an enthusiasm for science among young students, particularly those who attend the underserved schools of West Philadelphia. The PI will continue to develop microbiology experiments for use by schools having limited resources, and the lab will participate in in-class instruction as well as teacher-training workshops hosted by the University of Pennsylvania.

Recently, sensitive quantitative proteomics analyses have led to the identification of crucial components underpinning processes that are required for biofilm formation in bacteria and archaea. Thus far, however, few attempts to characterize differential protein expression patterns in planktonic cells, as compared to cells from various early stages of biofilm development, have been made. Moreover, given limited technological means, previous mass spectrometric (MS) studies of differential glycosylation during these transitions had not been performed, leaving the role played by this post-translational modification in biofilm formation poorly understood. However, recent technological advances in MS now allow generation of the most complete prokaryotic glycoproteome available, in both planktonic cells and biofilms, clarifying the mechanisms involved at various stages of biofilm formation. Using genetic and biochemical approaches in concert with quantitative glycoproteomics, the lab will focus on determining how differential expression and post-translational modifications of type IV pilins, which are subunits of the evolutionarily conserved cell surface structures, type IV pili, affect biofilm formation. These methods will likely also lead to the identification and characterization of other proteins that play roles in biofilm development. Because archaea and bacteria share many features in common, these studies will not only promote a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying archaeal biofilm formation but will also provide insights for those studying bacterial biofilms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microorganisms often encounter highly stressful environmental conditions, such as the presence of toxins or limited nutrient availability. The establishment of a biofilm — a complex microbial community surrounded by a protective matrix — is one strategy evolved by free swimming microbes to mitigate such stress. During the previous funding period, we used interdisciplinary approaches to identify, and partially characterize, novel mechanisms that regulate the transitions between a free-swimming cell and a biofilm-embedded sessile cell in the model microorganism, Haloferax volcanii. This research, supported by an NSF grant during the previous funding period, has resulted in the publication of twelve peer-reviewed research articles, supported the publication of an invited feature on Hfx. volcanii as well as four book chapters in “Methods in Molecular Biology: Archaea”. As part of our interdisciplinary approach, we used of high-throughput proteomics analyses to facilitate determinations of the sets of proteins that Hfx. volcanii expresses under various conditions. Furthermore, we extended these analyses to the identification of subsets of proteins that are modified post-translationally. In fact, using this approach, we generated what is, to date, the most comprehensive description of glycosylated proteins in any Archaea. Using the data generated in these proteomics analyses, we compared the patterns of protein expression and modifications in Hfx. volcanii grown under various conditions to begin unraveling the mechanisms that underpin such biological processes as morphogenesis and biofilm formation. To improve the efficiency and accuracy of our proteomics analyses, we developed new, cutting-edge bioinformatic tools and developed new experimental techniques, including an optimized biofilm assay that relies upon a 3D-printed multi-panel adhesion (mPAD) mount that facilitates efficient comparisons of the patterns of surface protein expression and PTMs in biofilm-associated cells and free-swimming planktonic cells. In addition to producing the most comprehensive proteome coverage for any archaeon to date, this project also resulted in improved genome annotations, showed that protein glycosylation can affect cell shape, revealed novel features of the cell biology and metabolism of Hfx. volcanii, and uncovered a surprising complexity in the regulation of protein glycosylation by concurrent glycosylation pathways. Recognizing the incredibly valuable insights afforded by comprehensive proteomics, we spearheaded the establishment of the Archaeal Proteome Project (ArcPP) during the current funding period, an extensive community effort that combines large-scale re-analysis of all proteomics datasets with interdisciplinary expert knowledge. This platform should prove to be an indispensable asset for researchers studying biological processes in other archaea as well Hfx. volcanii.

We used a similar approach in studies of the opportunistic pathogen, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which, as indicated by our preliminary data, also requires protein glycosylation in order to establish biofilms. We also characterized immersed liquid biofilms, which rather than adhering to an abiotic surface are free floating structures, and have discovered that these types of biofilms can form humidity-dependent honeycomb structures, perhaps as a means of facilitating dispersal. Finally, using biochemical and microscopic approaches, we made the first reported observations in any archaeon of cell wall growth that initiates from the mid-cell, while biochemical and genetic studies led to the identification of cell-shape mutants, including the first reported Hfx. volcanii mutants that are incapable of taking on a disk-shaped morphology. 

In hopes of contributing to an increased diversity in STEM, my lab hosted high school students while they carried out Science Fair experiments, and during each summer employed at least one URM high school student as part of the Penn Laboratory Experience in Natural Sciences (PennLENS) program. In this program, which I have served as faculty director from 2019-2021, rising 11th and 12th grade URM students from low-income families gain valuable experience working in a research lab, and  participate in group discussions, and other activities, supervised by a STEM high school teacher. In my lab, I continued to engage students from underserved high schools in research positions; all have continued in STEM and have been extremely successful. In fact, eight of the ten students who were supported by funding received from recent NSF grants co-authored at least one publication. In the Fall of 2020, I spearheaded the establishment of the Freshmen Exposure to Research in Biological Sciences (PennFERBS) program, a collaborative effort between the Biology Department and the Biochemistry & Molecular Biophysics (BMB) graduate group. PennFERBS provides incoming URM students with early research exposure and mentoring as well as experience in community building. Thus far PennFERBS has significantly increased retention of URM undergraduates in STEM majors, training of mentors, connecting with the community and providing leadership development.
